qas.question: What is the Alaska Permanent Fund?

plausible_answers.text: to manage a surplus in state petroleum revenues from oil

plausible_answers.text: fear that the legislature would spend the entire proceeds of the sale (which amounted to $900 million) at once

qas.question: Why did Governor Keith Miller propose the Alaska Permanent Fund after the Prudhoe Bay sale?

context: The Alaska Permanent Fund is a <a0_0><b5_0>constitutionally authorized appropriation of oil revenues<b5_0/><a0_0/>, established by voters in <a1_0><b6_0>1976<b6_0/><a1_0/> <a2_0><b7_0>to manage a surplus in state petroleum revenues from oil<b7_0/><a2_0/>, largely in anticipation of the recently constructed Trans-Alaska Pipeline System. The fund was originally proposed by <a3_0><b8_0>Governor Keith Miller<b8_0/><a3_0/> on the eve of the 1969 Prudhoe Bay lease sale, out of <a4_0><b9_0>fear that the legislature would spend the entire proceeds of the sale (which amounted to $900 million) at once<b9_0/><a4_0/>. It was later championed by Governor Jay Hammond and Kenai state representative Hugh Malone. It has served as an attractive political prospect ever since, diverting revenues which would normally be deposited into the general fund.
